content:
Gmail uses Oauth2, so you need to make sure a few things are set up correctly first.

Firewall: Access Firewall - it might be the defaulton computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus prgram. Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program.

VPN: Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some peopl who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use). Gmail does not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address, so gmail decides you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. Confirm VPN is switched off

Localhost: Do you have anything using the localhost? People who manage websites may typically use eg: Apache Xampp. You need to switch of any program using the localhost whilst setting up gmail. You can enable it again afterwards. I had to switch off Apache Xampp. Confirm nothing is using localhost.

In Thunderbird

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Web Content
  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Click on 'Exceptions' button
  • Enter this : https://accounts.google.com
  • Click on 'Allow
  • Click on 'Save Changes'
  • Whilst in that area - scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • If you see any mention of the account you are trying to set up - select the relevant lines and click on 'Remove'
  • Click on Close

I would switch off the following as it's still experimental.

  • Settings > General
  • Account Hub
  • uncheck this checkbox: 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'

Then create the mail account

  • Menu app > New Account > Email
  • Enter name
  • Enter gmail email address
  • Enter password
  • Select checkbox to remember password.
  • Click on 'Continue'

Thunderbird by default will look for the IMAP server settings. They should be:

  • Server name: imap.gmail.com
  • Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: OAuth2
  • Username = full gmail email address
  • Password is the same one you use to access webmail

Outgoing SMTP:

  • Server name: smtp.gmail.com
  • Port: 465
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: OAuth2
  • Username = full gmail email address
  • Password is the same one you use to access webmail

Assuming all is ok click on 'Done'

You should then get the gmail pop up browser type window. It will ask you to confirm you really are you and the then askif you want to allow Thunderbird access to server.

Then an OAuth token gets created and stored in the same place as all other passwords.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Ich gehe mal davon aus, dass du hunderte von Mails in jeweils neuen (eigenen) Tabs geöffnet hattest, bevor du Thunderbird beendet hast. Thunderbird macht automatisch bei jedem neuen Start eine Sitzungs-Wiederherstellung (session restore), d. h. er stellt die selbe Ansicht mit allen in der vorigen Sitzung benutzten Tabs und Fenstern wieder her. Da ich selber keine eigene Erfahrung mit so vielen offenen Tabs habe, vermute ich dass Thunderbird kurzzeitig so viel Prozessorlast beansprucht, dass er nicht mehr reagiert.

Du kannst folgende Lösung versuchen: • versichere dich, dass Thunderbird beendet ist • drücke die Windows Taste + R • tippe %APPDATA%\Thunderbird\Profiles\ in das Textfeld und klicke of OK • ein Fenster mit den Profilordnern wird geöffnet: identifiziere den aktuell benutzten Profilordner vom Typ xxxxxxxx.default-release (oder ähnlicher Name) anhand des letzten Änderungsdatums, öffne ihn, suche darin die Datei session.json und verschiebe sie auf den Desktop. Danach starte Thunderbird wieder und berichte...
creator: Mapenzi

content:
re :delete them from the server manually (with IMAP client) Are you saying you also have a mail account for same email address set up to use IMAP protocol? That sounds a bit odd since you are using a Pop account with set up to delete on download. Maybe you mean you are viewing the webmail account directly via a browser ?

What OS are you using ?

Do you have an Anti-Virus which is allowed to scan anything you download and any file that gets opened ?

What server are you talking about eg: gmail ?

Have you compacted the 'Inbox' folder recently? It might contain a load of 'marked as deleted' and 'hidden' emails. When you delete or move any email from eg: Inbox, the original is still in the file just marked as deleted. You would need to compact the folder in order to clean it up and remove all the old data. Important to keep files maintained as it reduces the risk of file corruption. It also reduces the file size. So basically anything you had deleted or moved would be communicated to server as fully deleted.


Maybe you have a program designed to 'clean up' what it determines as temp files, eg: CCleaner, WiseCleaner or even many Anti-Virus products can also do it. I would advise that you do not want any Anti-Virus or software cleanup programs accessing your Thunderbird profile folders as they can cause havoc, nuisance issues or even loss of data. Even if the Anti-Virus found something, you do not want it to do an auto fix or any fix because AV's do not understand that a single mbox text file may contain loads of emails. So a fix can end up with a complete loss of data in that file. In your case, as emails are deleted off server, it could a bit of a disaster. Access Anti-Virus products and set up a folder exemption to not scan your 'Thunderbird' profile folder - it will also not scan any of it's contents eg:

  • C:Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird


When you download emails to a Pop account, the mail account keeps a record of what has been downloaded in a 'popstate.dat' file. If that 'popstate.dat' file is corrupted or a new one keeps being created because something is deleting it, then Thunderbird does not know what has been downloaded, so it auto downloads whatever is in the 'Inbox' on server.

The best option is to do the following. I'm assuming you are using Windows OS and also that you downloaded/installed Thunderbird from the official website and not via Windows App Store as Windows puts profiles in a completely different location.

  • Exit Thunderbird - this is important

to Access Profile do this: - see image below as a guide

  • In windows search type : %Appdata%
  • Select the %Appdata% fle folder
  • Select 'Roaming' folder
  • Select 'Thunderbird' folder
  • Select the <profile name> folder
  • Select the 'Mail' folder
  • Select the <pop mail account name> folder

the pop mail account name folder should contain the 'popstate.dat' file. I've added an image showing an example of pop account. Do you see other popstate.dat files maybe with a number ?

Delete the 'popstate.dat' file because it's unknown if it is corrupted. When you restart Thunderbird, a new one gets created. The downside is that it will download everything again, but it should only do it the once.

It would also be useful if you could post an image that showed your Pop account Server settings - you can cover up the User name = email address as only that part is not required and it's private.

That would tell us the server and all your set up such as what you had selected eg:

  • Not selected/ unchecked: 'Leave messages on server'

Hi Maria,

Ignoring for now the strangeness of the second screenshot, which I don't know how you produced  … 

Font size, which you asked specifically about View menu > Font size > increase font size

Card or table view Your first image shows table view. Your second image shows card view. To switch between them, click on the icon of a film roll on the far right of the quick filter menu, and make your selection in the drop-down menu.

Folders You wrote: "When it opened up, all the existing emails were on the new iMac." But the second image shows folders that are not in the first image. Perhaps you have not subscribed to some folders on the server. Right click on the account name in the folder pane (rickandlupe@ix.netcom...), click on "Subscribe...", and select the server folders that you want to appear in Thunderbird.

Do you have questions about anything else?

content:
Zkontrolujte profil Thunderbirdu – složky často zůstanou fyzicky na disku. Lokální složky jsou uloženy zde: Windows: C:\Users\<uživatel>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<náhodný_profil>\Mail\Local Folders\

V této složce byste měli najít soubory bez přípony (např. MojeSlozka) a k nim soubor .msf (MojeSlozka.msf). Pokud soubor bez přípony existuje, data jsou zachranitelná. Pokud existují jen .msf, skutečná data jsou pryč.

creator: davidsk

content:
Some nefarious person has got hold of your email address and inserted the data in the To field. Your website mentions your email address, so it's publically available. The From name is not as relevant as recipient is based on TO email address. The From address may or may not exist but it's a reasonable guess based on your website domain.

Why ? Because they have worked out you are not going to set up you own email address as junk. They are hoping you get curious and click on some links or make a phone call, but they have also inserted a 'Reply-to' which may be real sender or some other poor person whom they have 'borrowed' an email address.

The best action is this: Delete the emails. Do not respond to them because that is likely to be counter productive and it will inform the sender that the email address is real and alive. So they may continue to abuse it. After deleting emails, compact the folder to rmove all traces from the mbox file.

After a while, they get bored when nobody responds. Please advise anyone who has access to seeing those emails to delete and not respond under any circumstance.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
This seems that it may be a common problem. When a person has two email addresses with the same domain, the two accounts sometimes attempt to use the same SMTP server. To check that, follow these steps carefully:

  1. click to account settings
  2. now, click the professional account in left sidebar
  3. notice the bottom line of the screen on right. click the 'edit smtp server' button. My guess is the email address shown will be for the other account. If I am correct, revert back to prior screen and click the dropdown menu for outgoing SMTP server. at that point, you should see both SMTP servers. Click the appropriate one and, for documentation, edit the description field to contain the professional email address. Now, revert back to prior screen and the bottom line pointing to outgoing server should now show the professional email address.
  4. now, send test email and let me know status.

creator: wsmwk

content:
Rural american ISP connection with speeds that are abysmal all the time IF a connection can be made. Might as well live in a cave in Nigeria for bandwidth. Due to the extortion of packet size/frequency demand of the network, outgoing Thunderbird messages will either fail to be sent (connection time-out) or fail to copy and process has to be started all over again. NONE of this is a fault of Thunderbird or relevant to what I just saw on examination of part of the problem: Version 115.4.2 was installed 11-20-23 BUT NEVER UPDATED SINCE BECAUSE THERE WERE ZERO notifications that updates were available despite the "Notify of Updates before installing" option chosen.

The only relevancy of connection speed is that I have to manage what sucks down my compute cycles because just an attachment on an email can make me smoke the dog, take a cigarette for a walk, brew a pot of coffee, come back and STILL be waiting to have thunderbird NOT drag down other functions while waiting for the attachements to save locally upon message acquisition (a function that I have not found how to disable).

I mistakenly wrote "right lower corner" when I meant "lower left corner" where the notice of how many emails are being downloaded flashes faster than the refresh rate of the eye (does anyone actually look at how they code this stuff?).

I have NEVER in my entire time on the internet gotten thousands of emails in a single batch. As noted these ghost messages did not appear ANYWHERE: not in the inbox, not in spam, and I don't know how to check to see if this was a creative hack if the 'messages' (or malware) were shunted to some other Thunderbird location, temp files or to local folders.

I will be updating the software manually, but that does nothing to answer the question of WHY in TWO YEARS I was never given notice of ANY updates whatsoever.

content:
This is the process I use: Please describe in detail what you did.


https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks David, I've followed that exact procedure 2 or 3 times now with the same result - everything is there on the new PC apart from the folders my friend created with the initial letter C onwards. Up until 2017/18 he was using a UK @btinternet.com email address with Thunderbird. All the folders he created whilst using this email address have been transferred successfully. Around 2018 he added a gmail email account and since then has been using this email address and creating folders into which he has been storing emails appropriately. The problem is with these folders he created after he started using his gmail account. Only 5 folders are present with the initial letters A and B. Everything from C onwards is missing. As I've said, I tried the Mozilla recommended methods a few times but each time I got the same result. Could there be a limit to the number of folders you can transfer? Any other ideas? Thank you.
creator: johnnief

content: My first step would be to look at the copied thunderbird folder from step 4, specifically the mail\Local Folders folder and the outlook express folders to see what was actually copied. That would be a good place to start or figuring why it's not appearing in thunderbird. My second step would be to click help>troubleshootinginformation in thunderbird, scroll down to 'profile folder', click 'open folder' and then look at the Mail\Local Folders folder and the outlook express folders to see what is there that thunderbird may not be seeing.

creator: wsmwk

content:
Setting up an account is easy. The hard part is that many users have no idea what the settings are from their email provider. Here are the basics: - click the hamburger menu in upper right - click new account>email - on this screen, enter just name and email address. If the email provider is well-known, thunderbird fills in all the information. To be safe, I suggest then clicking the 'manual setup' to review all the settings. Be sure that the full email address is used for the User Name field

That's it. you will be prompted for password after that. The settings for rackspace accounts is here: 

https://docs.rackspace.com/docs/rackspace-email-settings-copy
creator: davidsk

content:
Hi Alicia. There is no Thunderbird account that replaces other accounts. You will continue to use your Rackspace account and/or Apple account within Thunderbird.

You can switch the default e-mail app from something else to Thunderbird.
